newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ share mkt closes up 1.05 pct at 2-1/2 yr high.
newsitem.headline: NZ share mkt closes up 1.05 pct at 2-1/2 yr high.

text.p: * NZ share market pushes to 2-1/2 year high
* Telecom jumps to all-time high, Fletcher Forests strong
* Negative opinion poll for government shrugged off
The bulls were running again in the New Zealand share market on Friday as it surged a further one percent to end on a 2-1/2 year high.
Even the publication of a political opinion poll negative for the ruling conservative government just seven weeks ahead of the election failed to dampen enthusiasm.
The top 40 index ended 23.05 points ahead at 2222.59, its highest point since March 1994. Volume was a healthy $56 million.
And despite the market's 3.3 percent rise this week, brokers remain in bullish mood for the week ahead.
"There could be a correction, but I don't think you will see it upsetting the uptrend," said Cavill White's Don Turkington.
"The market doesn't seem worried about the prospect of the October 12 election," he said.
It was led up by the leaders, which brokers said was typical of a bull run. Firmly in the van was Telecom which jumped eight cents to an all-time high of $6.90.

Turkington said the break through previous highs was highly significant from a chart view as it had failed previously to break through the $6.80 and another failure would have seen that as an upper limit.
Telecom has risen 8.5 percent since its well received first quarter result last week.
Another star was Fletcher Forests which resumed its heavenly march since it and Brierley Investments won the bidding for Forestry Corporation on Tuesday. It closed up 10 cents at $2.04.
Carter Holt Harvey, one of the unsuccessful bidders, still rose strongly, up six cents to $3.26.
Even Wilson & Horton, which posted a below forecast half year profit on Thursday evening, rose 10 cents to $9.35.
Analysts were told by the company it was upbeat about its second half prospects.
